value="<font style="font-size: 18px;">Uniquely identifying DRKeys from RelTime while minimizing memory</font>" style="text;html=1;align=left;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="40" y="40" width="570" height="40" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="99X4dkrTFjrO0PwMJhht-2" value="<div style=""><span style="background-color: initial;">As stated in the SCION documentation [1] it is possible to uniquely identify the DRKey epoch by considering three candidate epochs.</span></div><div style="">This document shows that in LF we can achieve the same by only considering two epochs.&nbsp;</div><div style="">This is achieved by choosing the acceptance window small enough and good timing of the key update.</div><div style=""><br></div><div style=""><span style="background-color: initial;">[1] (<a href="https://scion.docs.anapaya.net/en/latest/protocols/authenticator-option.html#absolute-time-and-drkey-selection">https://scion.docs.anapaya.net/en/latest/protocols/authenticator-option.html#absolute-time-and-drkey-selection</a>)&nbsp;</span><br></div><div style=""><span style="background-color: initial;"><br></span></div><div style=""><span style="background-color: initial;"><br></span></div><div style=""><span style="background-color: initial;"><br></span></div><div style="">Below we differentiate different cases to show that in the LF setup it is always enough to only store two DRKeys.</div><div style="">Some words on notation:</div><div style=""><b>T</b> is the current time.</div><div style=""><b>Acc Win</b> is the acceptance window around <b>T</b>. Is must be smaller then the epoch len to uniquely identify a key.</div><div style=""><b>E<sub>i</sub></b> is always the currently active epoch. It holds therefore that&nbsp;<b>T ∈ E</b><sub style="font-weight: bold;">i</sub>.</div><div style=""><b>AbsTime</b> is the absolut time that the packet was sent.</div><div style=""><b>RelTime</b> is the relative timestamp that is sent in the SPAO header.</div><div style=""><b>at<sub>i-1</sub></b>, <b>at<sub>i</sub></b> and <b>at</b><sub style="font-weight: bold;">i+1 </sub>are the absolute times that can be calculated from the RelTime added to the corresponding epoch start times.&nbsp;</div>" style="text;html=1;align=left;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;container=0;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="40" y="100" width="730" div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 20px; margin-left: 2px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: nowrap;
div.font: Uniquely identifying DRKeys from RelTime while minimizing memory

switch.text: Uniquely identifying DRKeys from RelTime while minimizing memory

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 185px; margin-left: 2px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: nowrap;

div.span: As stated in the SCION documentation [1] it is possible to uniquely identify the DRKey epoch by considering three candidate epochs.

div.div: This document shows that in LF we can achieve the same by only considering two epochs.
This is achieved by choosing the acceptance window small enough and good timing of the key update.
Below we differentiate different cases to show that in the LF setup it is always enough to only store two DRKeys.
Acc Win is the acceptance window around T. Is must be smaller then the epoch len to uniquely identify a key.
Ei is always the currently active epoch. It holds therefore that T ∈ Ei.
AbsTime is the absolut time that the packet was sent.
RelTime is the relative timestamp that is sent in the SPAO header.
ati-1, ati and ati+1 are the absolute times that can be calculated from the RelTime added to the corresponding epoch start times.
